usefulItems: cling film, baking tray and paper, small plate (approx. Ø 20 cm), rolling pin, pastry brush, refrigerator, oven
title: Cornish Pasty

ingredients.content: 550 g strong white bread flour, plus extra for dusting
135 g butter, cold, diced plus extra for greasing

preparations.content: Place flour, butter, lard and salt in mixing bowl then mix <b>15 sec/speed 4<b>.
Add water and mix <b>10 sec/speed 4<b> then knead <b>3 min/<b>. Tip out and form into a flattened ball. Wrap in cling film and place in fridge to chill for 30 minutes. Meanwhile, make filling.
Place onions in mixing bowl and chop <b>5 sec/speed 5<b>. Tip out into a bowl and set aside.
Place beef in mixing bowl and chop <b>5 sec//speed 7<b>. Transfer to bowl with chopped onions.
Place bowl containing meat and onions on mixing bowl lid. Weigh in swede and potatoes then add salt and pepper. Mix together with spatula then set bowl aside.
Preheat oven to 160°C and line a large baking tray with baking paper.
Divide pastry in two then, on a lightly floured surface, roll each piece out until 3 mm thick. Using a small plate or cake tin base (approx. Ø 20 cm) as a guide, cut out six discs.

Divide mixture between pastry discs placing it on one half of each disc. Place a knob of butter on top of the filling. Brush the edges with beaten egg. Fold pastry over to make a half-moon shape, crimping the edges with fingers to seal. Brush tops with beaten egg then place on prepared baking tray and bake for 40-50 minutes (160°C) until golden brown and crisp. Allow to cool for a few minutes before eating.

hintsAndTricks: Increase oven temperature to 180°C for the last 10 minutes if the pasties are not browning.

Cornish pasties date back centuries although they reached their height of popularity when Victorian miners took them down the mines for their lunch. These D-shaped filled pastries provided a complete meal for the hard workers and helped sustain them throughout the day. They are a staple high-street snack nowadays…but much nicer when you make your own!
